description: I find it has some good features, indentation, replacing stuff, and auto-complete, I find { always making {} slightly annoying and similar for parentheses, some might have more or other features but personally I like and use Kate, not all I use because of those mentioned annoyances but this is like my main code editor maybe or maybe not, maybe.

KATE is the best of the project based editors I've tried. It's aimed very much at developers who dislike IDEs. So the features are designed more for people who like their code raw but need to keep projects organized. As a text editor it lacks a number of features and manages consume way too much memory to be a lightweight alternative to an office app. Memory leaks compound this. It is great for keeping a schema together for a large complex RDBMS or a Python app you break down into multiple files. I wish it had SQL support, including variations. Even more so I wish it had a text mode so it did not load all the programming language support thus making it far less resource intensive.

Super-fast, responsive, and full of features. Supports the VSCode LSP protocol, so you can use your favourite language servers. Maybe not quite as many features as VSCode, but the speed easily makes up for it.

Best GUI text editor on Linux.
Quite literally the best text editor out there, as good as notepad ++ in terms of functions, and as simple as Gedit m in addition to looking amazing.

Always wanted a simple text editor to edit my html and css AND for it to fit with other KDE programs. The Vscode does the job very well, I would even call it perfect but as I mentioned, electron, looks out of place. I keep coming back to Kate, trying it out only to see the simplest feature for a text editor - autocomplete, not implemented in a user-friendly way.
This time I spent an entire day to see if I can make it work with already included Emmet but without jumping through hoops to actually trigger it. Turns out it is not easy at all, all the forum posts suggests wild keybinding combinations - I don't want that and other text editors can do it, out of the box. Kate simply can not.
TLDR: windows notepad with bells and whistles.
Can't really complain about any KDE app. Kate is best.
just like many of the other kde apps, this text editor gives flexibility and features i didnt even know i needed, now i cant live without it.
"block editing" or column mode is very useful (Ctrl + Shift + B)
In fedora 24, we need to install qt5-qtx11extras and kf5-kwindowsystem as well or else the app crashes during start.
My favourite feature is Unicode recognising. Amazing!
One of the best cross-platform text editor for source code.
I have use kate for 5 years and not find any better.
summary: Easy to use and have all bells and whistles

description: On Debian 9 works perfect. This is my favourite text editor.
My favorite editor!
Kate is really nice lightweight alternatives to full-IDEs for quick code edits.
summary: Good editor for quick code edit

description: Competitive with features and usability with e.g. Atom or VSCode, but in a different league completely in terms of speed and resource utilization - so much lighter and faster! My favourite GUI text editor.

Kate is a ridiculously excellent text editor.

You know how in most other platforms, if you want a decent text editor, you need to go and find a third-party one like Sublime Text, Notepad++, or TextMate? Not so with Kate. It's so good that there's no need to replace it with something better.

In fact, for non-KDE users, it may *be* the better thing you replace your existing underpowered text editor with...
summary: No need to install anything else

description: Hugely functional stellar text editor. I like this better than sublime text and this is libre.
summary: Beautiful text editor with tons of functionality

description: Not to be confused with IDE though it can become one. For editor it the best of class.

- It's beautiful, supports dark theme, scrollbar with map (mini code preview) and codelens, also
  * wrap guide (vertical line at 80 column by default)
  * structure outline (vertical gides on the left to track indent)
- It's fast and responsive
 * quickly load and seamlessly works with large files (200 MB .json)
 * does not hang on searching large document, the search is done in background.
- Multiline edit is possible via rectangular selection feature
- Syntax highlight for a huge lot of languages
- Handy and customizable UI
I have been looking for a decent IDE for a while. I just assumed Kate was a notepad-like application. But I was very wrong! It has now replaced my bulky IDE and does everything I need.
summary: Very suprised by speed and number of features

description: I use Kate even on GNOME, it's worth it. Very powerful editor and fast.
Started using this in my Manjaro KDE environment and haven't looked back. No need for Sublime Text anymore on my Ubuntu GNOME environment!! Thank god

Kate has all the features and functionality one might expect in the profusion of text editors out there. But it does all of them well and comes with a huge extra -- the ability to temporarily act as su to save edits to a root-owned file. No need to run an entire session as root, just when it comes time to save the edits. This is ideal and prevents a lot of issues for mere mortals like me who are prone to err. I seriously love this text editor.

this is a very good snap.
All the features of packaged Kate are present.
Dark Theme works as is Light Theme

No reason to keek packaged Kate anymore, will replace it with snap.
Especially because on kubuntu packaged one is older than snap version.

It's just plain great from the get go. Doesn't take me more than a minute or two to customize a new install to my preferred setup. I'd give it an 11 if I could.

Bonus: If you do any work with BIOS modding, grab the "ACPI Source Language (DSDT) Highlighting" katepart from the KDE store and you'll be in heaven.
summary: Stellar apps like this keep me from DE hopping

description:
Great simple by default and complex when need editor.
It has alot of scripts and plugins that can be enable to support various editing needs.

Also the block editing option is great!
Awesome tool for text and code editing. Give it a try!
summary: Powerful and easy to use editor

description: Kate is great. The control + D shortcut to comment stuff out is amazing and the search and replace feature has saved me loads of time! Be good to be able to uncomment out as quickly too but not a big deal.
This editor comes with Kubuntu and I don't have much more to say about it. It has worked well.

Keep going!
Very impressive work.
when i edit or open the file it loads nothing, blank file openinig
summary: text not loading on kate file

description: The best replacement for notepad++ comming from windows rnvironments.
It's like notepad++, but it has an even cleaner interface and more options. I love this text editor!
Why i have two icons ? How to fix this ?

An amazing, ligght weight text editor and DE for programming. I use it frequently for C/C++ dev as it inherently recognizes many of the most popular programming languages and not only colorize/stylize's them to fit that language's syntax but also auto-fixes syntax to make code easier to read. It also allows you to collapse functions which you dont need to view. All the best ideas for real programming. There are so many other features I simply have not had a chance to use yet. Highly Recommend!
You can open a folder properly which is a shame for even a simple text editor, also i shows two icons in Ubuntu 20.04 for some reason. Can not recommend unfortunately.
Can't ask for much more, yet always so fast. I use it literally every day for writing code, notes, and opening stuff that I have no idea what it is, Kate recognizes the format usually.

I love the way you can use block select and it colors your code. It's inutitive in my opinion and works fast. Also i think the 'copy file path' function is very useful in combination with the terminal.

This is the first text editor that has impressed me.

The yellow select highlight feature is amazing to use for my purposes.
I have used kate for years to hand code html tags. Not just for web domains but for writing essays and sermons in html. Nothing else comes close. chj3
Wanted to edit xorg.conf, but kate says i don't have read permission.
i like it , its very powerfull
Wont let me install it. Really strange .

summary: Seemed like a great app when I was able to use it

description: Lightweight and Powerful. Excellent integration with other KDE-Tools. Good plugins.
Unable to create io-slave. klauncher said: Error loading '/snap/kate/91/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/qt5/plugins/kf5/kio/file.so'.
It is under constant development and has a great potential!

Installed it on a quite fresh Ubuntu 20.04, and the mouse pointer won't leave the loading/hourglass state, which is pretty annoying.

Also I had a look at some of the functions and settings and already missed several of the things that I would have expected and why I considered switching from gedit, like auto-indents for instance.

The best thing I can say about Kate is that it looks a lot better than its greatest competitor, Sublime Text, which is so badly designed that I didn't even spend more than five minutes with it. Kate however COULD be great, if some issues get fixed and some features get added ...
summary: Looks promising, but fails at the basic level

description: Event though it is good but VSCode is absolutely better than it. I would rather use that instead.
Great features but not not much good to a user if it randomly deletes the contents of a saved session.
Nice text editor, packaged with Kubuntu with multi tabs. Better than gedit.
It's got lots of features, but the UI is rather clunky.
It is very useful, good performance and beautiful UI.
Best text editor
Is much more then a simple text editor
the terminal option within the editor is just great
Fully half as good as Emacs, and notably faster!

Wow has kde-in-general has come so far.

Kate pulls you in quickly with a buttery-rich feature set.
Beautifully customizable interface.
MindBlowing.
summary: Superb! I could get used to this. =)

description: Very nice Text Editor
A great, lightweight text editor full of features. It has all you need and would ever want!
I think adding support for 3rd party plugins and making it easier to install with a plugin marketplace will be very useful, it can then become a proper replacement for github atom
Almost no complains, thank you.

I love using Kate!
It is the best and easiest Text program out there (other than nano, but nano does not have a gui)!

No crazy key combinations necessary as it uses standard key combinations like ctrl+c to copy and ctrl+v to paste. It's simple and easy to use!
EXTREMELY fast, feature-rich yet simple to use. I love it. I wish there were more themes and plugins though.
Fast an featureful
Im using gnome and plasma,the dark theme is terrible in gnome,its best to use in plasma.
I do not use text editors that use spaces for tabs without the ability to change the settings. Changing indentation to use tabs will still use spaces. It might be usable if this bug is fixed.

I have drug this editor through every flavor of debian/ubuntu OS's I could find, a trooper i never leave behind. Only flaw is that if its not a KDE/Plasma build and you install it manually with the "suggests" then you will basically have kde/Plasma framework in the Distro you are using. The 45 mins and 4GB is not an issue for me, i prefer KDE but with a Plasma/Gnome twist and KDE doesnt always easily support Gnome 41+ in its native builds. So in the end I get the best of a polyamorous situation kate, plasma and gnome together in one build.
summary: Amazing! It would even change the baby's diapers (if I had a baby!?)

description: I like to use it to edit python and xml files. The advanced search is great as I can search-replace and also use regex. It is better than using very heavy text editor also working as IDE.
ast, smooth, wide range of settings. Love It!
summary: Fast, smooth, wide range of settings. Love It!

description: I love using Kate as my daily text editor. While it's not the tool for every text editing job (sometimes a terminal-based one is better, sometimes a full IDE is what you need), it covers a broad swath of usages. Kate and Firefox are honestly the two apps I feel like are just always running on my machine.

Kate is now a modern, easy-to-use and featureful text editor. It has the potential to overtake VS Code For the best experience, make sure to install LSP servers for your languages (which should be made easier).
Stopped working after actually forced update. Re-installation did not help. Editor looks good, but unreliable. Stay away if you value your time.
The only thing I needed which I couldn't get is tags auto closing in HTML.
best till date on linux
Facil de usar e simples para desenvolvedores que querem apenas focar no código. Estou adotando Kate com o meu editor de código primario para a maioria dos meu projetos.

I had hoped that Kate would be a good Linux replacement for Notepad++ on Windows, and it gets very close. But it's unusable because it randomly (every few months) completely forgets my default session state, so all my tabs (opened files) are gone. And if I open a file when Kate isn't running, then it does NOT restore my last session, but opens that file on it's own - which might be a contributing factor in how my default session gets wiped.
summary: Almost great, but is unusable as it randomly forgets my session state

description: After every setup Kate is one of the first things I install. It's the best

very useful feature set, i'm sticking with this over "gnome-text-editor" for now. 
In another review, "Chris" complained about it not loading all previously-open files when first lauched on a file, but for me that's how I like it.
If you spend a lot of time editing a set of files and don't want to have go find them again, maybe use the "saved sessions" feature?
summary: Agree with most everybody else: Excellent

description: I can't use another editor that doesn't have sessions.
I love Kate for my editor. I've installed it on my Windows and Mac machines too. I've been using Geany for a long time, but I like Kate better.
Although it is a little bloated with GIT features, this is one of the best graphical editors available for Linux.
'Elisa' the media player and 'Kate' the word processor. Why are we shifting every major program type to have girls' names? To be secretarial? Where's 'Justin' and 'Ingram'?
Working very well, I mainly use it for programming.
summary: Very good text editor, worked very well

description: Very comfortable, well designed and workes great.
Its become a staple of my enviorment.
A lot of the same functionalities of Notepad++, much faster than VSCode and multiplatform. It is a serious lightweight editor that's worth to install and learn to use...

Due to unknown circumstances the text editor often does not allow me to delete text. I have to save what I wrote reopen the program again and the bug is fixed temporarly.I am using Nobara os 39, but this happend to me as well in Fedora 39,38. Overall I like the text editor but this glitch is annoying. Please fix it !

amazing text editor
does everything i need it to do

Doesn't work with a dark themed Gnome DE. There are, apparently dark themes available, but about half of the UI stays light themed, meaning that you end up with light text on light backgrounds or vice versa, rendering it not only unusable, but also hideous.
Someone needs to throw Qt into the sea.
and has lots of features too; super handy

Not really any complaint. Kate is great because it is lightweight but can be as crazy as you want it to be, really following KDE's philosophy of simple by default but powerful when needed. You can either edit a simple text file or write C or rust or python e.t.c. with full LSP support and whatnot.
best gui text editor out there - it works, it has all the features I want, no complaints

It's pretty much the "KDE Plasma" of text editors. Simple by default but can get very powerful when needed. I use it as a fully fledged IDE with language server and debug adapter support! 

My favorite part is that I do not need to download plugins. They're already there and I can toggle them on and off based on what I need.

Supports many programming languages too, and if there's no syntax highlighting, one can always contribute a new one.

I've been contributing to the project as well and the maintainers are happy to receive patches and changes, so I'd say it's also very hackable editor if you're into tinkering with QtWidgets 

Worth a try, spend some time with it and see how it fits your needs!
summary: My favorite text editor so far

description: Been using this for years now, I don't think it's ever crashed or even glitched. I do a lot of text editing (not programming) and I appreciate how quick and easy and capable it is for editing large text files.
Der Editor läuft bei mir sowohl unter Debian12 (KDE-Plasma), als auch Ubuntu24.04 (Gnome) absolut einwandfrei. Vom Funtkionsumfang in etwa mit Notepad++ zu vergleichen.
mit Gnome kann niemand klarkommen, deshalb eben KDE.
Have not found anything better yet!
Für Alles anwendbar

Bis auf Fehleruntersuchung ist für mich alles relevante drinnen - debugging und co macht man halt über das Terminalfenster. Das sorgt auch für eine schnelle Bedienung.
Für Projekte im Frühstadium sehr nützlich, da es einfach nicht in den Weg kommt, und gleichzeitig nützliche Tools wie zB Sitzungen bietet.
Einfach super, und eun guter Gegenspieler zu VS Code, Sublime und Notepad++

Don't miss anything, you can do everything with it.
Now they should perhaps make sure that the clarity of the many features is not lost.

Very complex and modular Editor for A LOT of languages.

You can use it for flat text (.txt), markdown with customizable Preview using Okular extension, HTML, export of Markdown using pandoc plugin,....

Has highlightes syntax for a lot of languages.

Handles Tabs customizable.

Very verstitle text editor. If you need a more leightweight alternative to VS Code this will also be suitable because of the implementation in C++, support for syntax highlighting in a ton of languages, integrated terminal window and git integration.
wird aktualisiert und funktioniert.
Kate ist super, übersichtlich, vielseitig und effizient.
Mas completo que Kwrite, da información mediante colores para indicar cambios etc. Sirve sobre todo para archivos de configuración.
Todo para poder programar, de verdad lo prefiero.
De los mejores editores de textos. Simple y perfecto.
demasiado util en el dia a dia
KATE es de mis editores favoritos. Muy versatil.
summary: Simple. ligero. Uno de los mejores editor de texto

description: Como editor de notas, creo que es el mejor que he probado. Sólo he echado de menos que le de formato al código como sí hace Vim (gg=G). Se puede, pero hay que instalar paquetes extra y no queda tan bién. Le pongo 4 estrellas porque no puedo dar 4.5.
summary: Sólo le falta dar formato al código

description: funciona muy bien cumple su funcion
Con diferencia el mejor editor por defecto que he visto en un sistema.
Siempre me gustó mucho. Es sencillo en el buen sentido, y cumple con creces lo poco que promete.
summary: Excelente como editor y como IDE

description: Good ap	je recommande.
doublon avec l'éditeur de texte déjà installé. A mon niveau, n'apporte rien de plus. Par la suite impossible à désinstaller, tourne en boucle après avoir validé la désinstallation.

Cette version 17 contient un bug qui casse les hardlinks et a créé de gros problèmes de pertes de données et démultiplication des données pour moi et d'autres. A éviter !
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38945393/using-hard-link-with-kate-editor

Choisir l'autre version de Kate proposée : la version 19 qui résoud ce problème (et ajoute de nombreuses autres améliorations)
summary: Cette version 17 est bugguée, choisir la version 19 à la place !

description: Parfaitement fonctionnelle.

J'aime le mode sombre, la barre de navigation, les sessions, le tri,
la gestion de l'encodage des fichiers, scinder les fenêtres à volonté,
les sessions, le grand choix de langages supportés, la coloration syntaxique, le mode édition par bloc, l'accès au terminal. 

Pas de soucis pour éditer du MarkDown ou du Rust.

Le client LSP nécessite d'installer rust-analyzer par ailleurs pour que ça fonctionne. Kate devient alors très puissant comme éditeur de code source. 

Concernant l'intégration à git, il y a aussi des installations à faire avant que ce soit fonctionnel. 

L'interface est perfectible sur certains points, mais globalement c'est un éditeur agréable à utiliser.
summary: Excellent éditeur de texte, à prendre en main

description: The best text editor I ever tried
Не запускаеться as root :(
summary: Ну да этот "Gold" совсем не Gold

после gedit кажется очень функциональным

Самый лучший текстовый редактор, который корректно отображает кириллицу и английский текст. Много настроек. Всё понятно.
Самый лучший текстовый редактор. Корректно отображает русский язык. Много шикарных настроек.

比 vscode 轻量，而且功能强大，运行稳定。是各种重量级 IDE 的最佳补充软件。
